title: Steam Header – Blocked Outlet
description: A high-pressure steam header feeds multiple process units. A downstream isolation valve may be inadvertently closed, creating a blocked outlet scenario. The PSV must protect the header from overpressure. Discharge is to atmosphere via a silencer.
constraints: Discharge to atmosphere (no backpressure concerns)
Set pressure at MAWP of 150 psig
Steam is saturated at relieving conditions
No variable backpressure – conventional valve acceptable

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Steam Header
attachments.contentRef: Steam header at 150 psig MAWP. Supply from boiler house. Feeds Unit 100, Unit 200, Unit 300. PSV-101 protects header. Discharge routed to atmosphere via silencer. No backpressure header.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Maximum steam flow from boiler: 25,000 lb/hr. In blocked outlet scenario, full boiler output must be relieved. Steam properties at 150 psig saturated: T = 366°F, MW = 18.02, k = 1.33, Z ≈ 0.95.

title: Gas Service to Flare – Variable Backpressure
description: A process gas compressor discharge vessel requires overpressure protection. The PSV discharges to a common flare header shared with multiple units. During upset conditions, flare header pressure can fluctuate significantly, creating variable backpressure concerns.
constraints: Discharge to flare header (variable backpressure)
Superimposed backpressure: 15-45 psig (variable)
Built-up backpressure must be considered
Backpressure exceeds 10% of set pressure – conventional valve NOT suitable
Set pressure at 200 psig

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Compressor Discharge
attachments.contentRef: Compressor K-101 discharge vessel V-101. MAWP 200 psig. PSV-201 on vessel top. Discharge ties into 8" flare header. Header serves Units 100-400. Note: Flare header pressure varies 15-45 psig during upsets.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Relief case: Control valve failure (FV-101 fails open). Max flow: 15,000 lb/hr. Gas: Hydrocarbon mix, MW=32, k=1.25, Z=0.92. Relieving temp: 250°F. Expected built-up BP in discharge piping: ~20 psig.

title: Liquid Thermal Expansion Case
description: A heat exchanger shell containing a liquid hydrocarbon can be blocked in during maintenance or turnaround. Solar radiation or residual heat can cause thermal expansion of the trapped liquid. A thermal relief valve is required to prevent hydraulic overpressure.
constraints: Thermal expansion case – small flow, critical selection
Liquid service – volumetric flow basis
Discharge to closed drain system
Set pressure at 75 psig (exchanger MAWP)
Minimal backpressure in closed drain

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Heat Exchanger E-101
attachments.contentRef: Shell & Tube Exchanger E-101. Shell side: Light hydrocarbon liquid. MAWP 75 psig. Block valves on inlet/outlet allow isolation. PSV-301 (thermal relief) on shell. Discharge to closed drain header.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Thermal expansion relief: Expected flow ~3 GPM based on heat input calculation. Fluid: Light naphtha, SG=0.68, viscosity ~0.5 cP. Relieving temp assumed 150°F. Closed drain header pressure negligible (<5 psig).

title: [HARD] High Backpressure PSV – Critical Flare Scenario
description: A high-pressure separator requires overpressure protection during a fire case scenario. The PSV discharges to an overloaded flare system with extremely variable backpressure. This challenging scenario requires careful backpressure analysis and valve selection to avoid catastrophic failure.
constraints: Fire case relieving scenario – external fire on vessel
Superimposed backpressure: 30-75 psig (highly variable)
Total backpressure may exceed 50% of set pressure during peak events
Set pressure at 285 psig (vessel MAWP)
Pilot valve may be required for this high backpressure range
Backpressure correction factor critical for sizing

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – HP Separator V-201
attachments.contentRef: High Pressure Separator V-201. MAWP 285 psig. Vessel in fire zone per API 2000 analysis. PSV-401 on vapor space. Discharge to 12" flare header. Header serves multiple units and is frequently overloaded. WARNING: Flare header backpressure has reached 75 psig during simultaneous relief events.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Fire case per API 521: Wetted area 850 sq ft. Relief load: 85,000 lb/hr. Gas: Light hydrocarbon vapor, MW=44, k=1.15, Z=0.88. Relieving temp: 400°F. Built-up BP from discharge piping: ~35 psig. CRITICAL: Conventional valves have failed in this service due to backpressure-induced set point shift.

attachments.title: Historical Incident Note
attachments.contentRef: LESSON LEARNED: A previous installation used a bellows valve that experienced bellows failure due to overpressure. Root cause: Total backpressure exceeded bellows rating during simultaneous relief. Consider pilot-operated valve for this high backpressure application.

title: [HARD] Tank Fire Case with VRU Integration
description: An atmospheric storage tank requires emergency venting protection for fire case. The tank has both a normal vent (to VRU) and emergency vent (to atmosphere). The scenario involves complex vapor recovery unit (VRU) integration and requires understanding of tank breathing, fire relief, and arrester placement.
constraints: Atmospheric tank fire case – API 2000 emergency venting
Normal operation vents to Vapor Recovery Unit (VRU)
Emergency vent must bypass VRU and vent to atmosphere
Flame arrester required on atmospheric discharge
Conservation vent + emergency vent combination
Set pressure: 0.5 psig (very low pressure tank)
Arrester pressure drop must be included in sizing

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Tank T-301
attachments.contentRef: Atmospheric Storage Tank T-301. Design pressure: 1.0 psig / -0.5 psig. Stores crude oil. Normal vent line to VRU header. Emergency vent VV-301 direct to atmosphere. Flame arrester FA-301 on emergency vent outlet. HH level alarm at 95%. Shutdown on HHH at 98%.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Fire case per API 2000 Table 4: Tank diameter 50 ft, height 40 ft. Wetted area: 6,283 sq ft. Emergency vent requirement: 750,000 SCFH. Normal breathing handled by conservation vent. Gas properties: MW=65 (heavy ends), k=1.08. Flame arrester dP: 2 inwc at rated flow.

attachments.title: VRU Integration Note
attachments.contentRef: VRU capacity: 500 SCFM at 0.25 psig suction. VRU cannot handle fire case flows. Emergency vent must lift before tank approaches MAWP. Conservation vent setting: +0.5/-0.25 psig. Emergency vent setting: +0.75 psig. RISK: Arrester plugging from product carryover – inspect monthly.

title: [HARD] Overfill Protection System Design
description: A critical loading rack requires overfill protection per API 2350. The scenario involves high-level shutdown integration, independent high-high level alarm, and emergency vent sizing for maximum pumping rate. This tests understanding of overfill prevention layers and relief device coordination.
constraints: Overfill protection case – maximum transfer rate
API 2350 Category 3 system required
Independent HH alarm and HHH shutdown
Relief valve sized for pump dead-head + thermal effects
Liquid service with potential two-phase flash
Discharge to containment sump
Set pressure at 15 psig (tank truck MAWP)

attachments.title: P&ID Snippet – Loading Rack LR-101
attachments.contentRef: Tank Truck Loading Rack LR-101. Transfer pump P-101 rated 500 GPM at 50 psig. Independent level instruments: LI-101 (normal), LAH-101 (high alarm), LAHH-101 (high-high shutdown). PSV-501 on loading header downstream of pump. Discharge to containment sump. Truck MAWP: 15 psig.

attachments.title: Process Note
attachments.contentRef: Product: Gasoline, SG=0.73, viscosity 0.5 cP, RVP 9 psia. Max transfer rate: 500 GPM. Dead-head pressure: 85 psig. Thermal relief consideration: Blocked-in volume may expand 0.5% from solar heating. PSV must handle pump runout (550 GPM) plus thermal contribution.

attachments.title: API 2350 Requirements
attachments.contentRef: API 2350 Category 3 requires: (1) Automatic tank gauging, (2) Independent high level alarm, (3) Independent high-high shutdown, (4) Overfill prevention system test annually. CRITICAL: Level instruments must be independent – no common sensing element. PSV is last line of defense, not primary protection.
